description: From Middle English bestial, from Old French bestial, from Late Latin bēstiālis, from Latin bēstia (“beast”) (whence English beast).

adjectives.description: bestial (comparative more bestial, superlative most bestial)

examples: His was a bestial face, a face that bore the stamp of Nature's eternal injustice.

description: From Middle Scots bestiall, from Middle English bestaile, from Old French bestaille, from Late Latin bēstiālia; later reinforced and remodelled on Middle French bestial, itself from Late Latin bēstiālis.

examples: […]  much must depend upon the way in which bestial are bought or reared, and the state of the markets when they are sold.
